docs.lead_paragraph: About 2,000 employees of ABC walked off their jobs without warning yesterday for a 24-hour strike, and the television network's management responded by saying it would lock out any striking workers who try to return today. The network said temporary workers would be hired to replace the employees who took part in the strike, which started at 5 A.M. and which union officials said was staged over a health-care issue.

headline.main: ABC Workers Stage 24-Hour Strike; Lockout Is Response

docs.abstract: About 2,000 employees of ABC walk off their jobs without warning for 24-hour strike and television network's management responds by saying it will lock out any striking workers who try to return; network says that it will hire temporary workers to replace strikers; officials of National Assn of Broadcast Engineers and Technicians say walkout was staged over health care issue (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A convicted serial killer who had asked to be executed apparently attempted to commit suicide early this morning, officials said. A guard found the inmate, Michael B. Ross, lying on the floor of his cell at 1:25 A.M. this morning, during the guard's twice-hourly patrol of Connecticut's death row, said Captain S. Scott Semple of the Connecticut Department of Correction. Mr. Ross was taken from Northern Correctional Institution in Somers to the University of Connecticut Health Center in Farmington at 4 A.M., Mr. Semple said.

headline.main: Serial Killer in Connecticut May Have Tried Suicide With Drugs

docs.abstract: Michael B Ross, convicted serial killer who had asked to be executed, apparently attempted to commit suicide in his prison cell, Hartford, Conn (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Cigna Corporation said today that its third-quarter earnings fell 8 percent as the insurance company paid out claims for damages related to Hurricane Georges. The company's profit for the quarter, excluding investment gains, fell to $241 million, or $1.14 a diluted share, compared with $262 million, or $1.17 a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Cigna, which bolstered its per-share earnings by buying back stock, was expected to earn $1.12 a share based on the average estimate of analysts polled by the First Call Corporation, which tracks company earnings. Revenue rose less than 1 percent, to $5.23 billion from $5.18 billion. Cigna, which has been focusing more on group insurance plans over slower-growing individual insurance policies, said it had profit of $159 million from its group health and life insurance division, up from $128 million.
docs.abstract: Cigna Corp says third-quarter earnings fell 8 percent; profit fell to $241 million compared with $262 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose less than 1 percent, to $5.32 billion from $5.18 billion (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Sharon McCormack of White Salmon, Wash., loved windsurfing the Columbia River Gorge, but she had a problem on the big jumps: Her contact lenses washed out. ''Or I got dust under a lens,'' she said. ''That's incredibly painful.'' Ms. McCormack solved the problem by having laser surgery to correct her nearsightedness. More than 400,000 laser vision procedures will be done this year, industry sources say, most of them for nearsightedness, or myopia, like Ms. McCormack's. But next year, farsighted surfers and others may be having laser surgery, too.

headline.main: Lasers May Soon Be Used to Treat Farsightedness

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration may approve laser treatment for farsightedness by year's end; photo; drawings illustrate conditions of nearsightedness, or myopia, and farsightedness, or hyperopia; and how lasers can correct conditions (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Working part time used to mean afternoons at home or two or three days off a week. But as many Americans find themselves working weeks that stretch to 60 or more hours, ''part time'' can mean something very different: the ability to leave the office most nights at 5 or schedule a half-day off every other week. A new class of part-timers, mostly women, is emerging and working what used to be considered full-time hours -- 35 or 40 hours a week. Lawyers, consultants, managers and other professionals, they want to cut back their official hours so they can spend more time with their children or deal with other responsibilities. They want the freedom to miss a meeting occasionally to drop in on a Tumbling Tots class or visit an ailing parent.

headline.main: Part-Time Work for Some Adds Up to Full-Time Job

docs.abstract: New class of part-time workers is emerging: mostly women and mostly professionals, who work 35 or 40 hours a week, what used to be considered full-time hours; trend reflects greater number of professional and management-level women, increase in number of dual-career couples and lengthening of average workweek for professional or manager over last 20 years to almost 48 hours from 45; new 'part-timers' want to keep careers while spending more time with their children and handling other responsibilities; some are trying to manage nearly same workload as full-timers by working more at home and working more efficiently at office; others are cutting workloads; although they typically collect benefits, many take cut in pay; some employees are thrilled with new flexibility, but many are frustrated by perception among supervisors and colleagues that they are somehow shirking work unless they are in the office as long as everyone else; charts; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Working part time used to mean afternoons at home or two or three days off a week. But as many Americans find themselves working weeks that stretch to 60 or more hours, ''part time'' can mean something very different: the ability to leave the office...

docs.lead_paragraph: Peter F. Vallone, the Democratic candidate for Governor, debated what he called ''an empty chair'' yesterday, participating in a televised forum without his Republican opponent, Governor George E. Pataki, who skipped the event and stumped upstate. The Governor, who spoke to reporters at a Republican Party rally in Albany, said he had bypassed yesterday's face-off on WNBC-TV with Mr. Vallone, as well as other proposed debates, because the Democratic candidate ''just never stopped with the personal attacks.''

headline.main: Vallone Debates Alone as Pataki Draws Fire from Golisano for Ad Campaign

docs.abstract: Peter F Vallone, Democratic candidate for Governor of New York, is interviewed on NBC-TV by Gabe Pressman as alternative to debate with Gov George Pataki, who has rejected proposals to debate Vallone; B Thomas Golisano, Independence Party candidate, attacks series of ads produced by Pataki campaign that accuses Golisano of favoring legalized drugs and prostitution; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a day of old-style politicking, Representative Charles E. Schumer campaigned for the Senate in black, Jewish and Hispanic neighborhoods across New York City yesterday, bringing in Vice President Al Gore in an attempt to rally support in tomorrow's election. Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato went to Orthodox Jewish communities in Brooklyn, portraying himself as an underdog in the final weekend of the bruising race. Mr. D'Amato gave brief speeches yesterday at two rallies in Brooklyn before conservative Jews in Borough Park and Williamsburg -- a reliable and enthusiastic part of his political base. Both rallies drew fairly large crowds, but both were notable for their lack of obvious enthusiasm.

headline.main: Parties Pushing Message: Your Vote Counts

docs.abstract: Repr Charles E Schumer campaigns for US Senate in black, Jewish and Hispanic neighborhoods across New York City, joined by Vice Pres Al Gore; Sen Alfonse D'Amato campaigns with Mayor Rudolph Giuliani in Orthodox Jewish communities in Brooklyn; D'Amato tells supporters not to be discouraged by polls or pundits that suggest campaign is in trouble; Schumer steers away from attacks on D'Amato that have been at heart of his campaign; delivers most upbeat messages in weeks, pledging to unify state's diverse regions and communities and focusing on core Democratic themes; photos (M)

byline.original: By JAMES DAO and ADAM NAGOURNEY

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: B. Thomas Golisano ECONOMY AND TAXES -- Centerpiece of his campaign is an attack on Mr. Pataki for raising state debt, and says he would reduce it. Criticizes Mr. Pataki's use of financial incentives to business, saying they should be linked to guarantees of job retention over a specific period of years. Advocates elimination of Thruway tolls. Says state spending should be reduced, but does not say how. EDUCATION -- Supports charter schools. Says schools should be made to meet performance standards and reduce administrative costs. Advocates a freeze on public college tuition, and says the colleges should focus more on computer technology. Says schools should expand occupational training for students who are not academically oriented and are likely to drop out. CRIME -- Says the state should spend much more money on drug education and treatment, as an alternative to prison for nonviolent drug offenders. Supports the death penalty. Does not support stronger gun-control laws. Criticizes the current justice system as putting too many people in prison, but does not say what the alternative is. CAMPAIGN FINANCE -- Advocates term limits as the best way to limit the financial advantage of incumbents. But does not support restrictions on contributions, soft money or transfers from one committee to another. HEALTH CARE -- Says he will conduct a thorough investigation of Medicaid to find areas where spending could be cut. Opposes forcing health insurers to cover contraceptives. Advocates expansion of medical savings accounts for people to help cover health care costs. George E. Pataki ECONOMY AND TAXES -- Has consistently worked to lower taxes, most importantly those on income, property and business profits. Says he will continue to cut taxes in a second term, but does not give specifics. Aggressively promotes the use of financial incentives like tax breaks, loans, low-cost electric power to retain employers in New York State and to attract new ones. EDUCATION -- Signed into law state program to make kindergarten and prekindergarten classes available in every community, and to lower elementary class sizes by 2002. Strong advocate of charter schools, specialized schools that operate outside the usual bureaucratic restraints, which are opposed by teacher unions. Has agreed to major increases in education spending, but vetoed money to increase teachers' salaries and speed up school construction. Cut subsidies for public colleges and imposed a $750-a-year tuition increase, but also won a $3 billion capital improvement program for the campuses. CRIME -- Won re-enactment of the death penalty, tougher penalties for violent crimes and sharp limitations on parole. Advocates tougher sentences for juvenile offenders. Enacted state's first program of sending drug offenders to treatment rather than prison, but it is small in scope. Has said he favors easing state's strict drug-possession penalties. Supports continued prison construction. CAMPAIGN FINANCE -- Has said he dislikes the current system, but has not said how he would change it. Disapproves of advocacy groups independent of campaigns advertising for or against a candidate, and of wealthy people running for office with their own money, but says he does not think either one can be restrained legally. Has not taken a position on whether the state's high contribution limits should be lower, or whether soft money and transfers from one political committee to another should be limited. Opposes public financing. HEALTH CARE -- Has cut back Medicaid, the health insurance program for the poor, but has expanded health care programs for poor children. Has not said what he would do to help the three million New Yorkers without medical coverage. Betsy McCaughey Ross ECONOMY AND TAXES -- Favors mandating lower utility rates, greater tax credits for investment in research, and large-scale government investment in training adults for high-tech jobs. EDUCATION -- Was one of the prime forces behind the universal kindergarten and prekindergarten program signed by Mr. Pataki, now being carried out. Proposes an aggressive reading program for children in the early grades, and earlier testing to catch those children who cannot read. CRIME -- Supports capital punishment. Advocates laws requiring trigger locks on handguns, and laws holding adults legally responsible when their children cause injury or death with a gun. Supports greater use of drug treatment as an alternative to incarceration. CAMPAIGN FINANCE -- Favors banning soft money, and limiting contributions by special interests, particularly health insurers. HEALTH CARE -- Advocates giving patients the right to appeal to an independent panel of experts when their insurers deny coverage for a treatment, and says a law enacted this year to do that does not go far enough. Supports similar appeals system to obtain coverage for experimental treatment of people who are gravely ill. Says law should be changed to allow patients to sue health insurers for denial of coverage. Peter F. Vallone ECONOMY AND TAXES -- Voted several times in the 1980's for higher taxes, and was a prime force behind a 1991 city income tax increase to expand the Police Department. But has worked frequently since then to lower taxes, and led the way this year in rescinding the 1991 increase. Says the state will have trouble paying for Mr. Pataki's property tax cuts, but would not repeal them. Says surpluses should be used to pay off state debts. Calls the Governor's tax breaks to companies ''corporate welfare.'' Major economic development idea is to have the state give preference to New York companies in awarding contracts. EDUCATION -- Says public college tuition should be cut in half for students who maintain a B average. Advocates state-financed, educational after-school program at every school, but is vague about how to pay for it. Supports effort to make kindergarten and prekindergarten available in every community, and to lower elementary-school class sizes. Says the state budget surplus should have been used to speed up those efforts, rather than to pay for tax cuts. Says he does not oppose charter schools, but would want guarantees that other schools would not get less money and that teachers' job security would not be threatened. CRIME -- Supports the death penalty, and has backed tougher penalties for serious crimes. Says low-level drug offenders should be allowed to enter treatment instead of prison. Questions need for new prisons. Sponsored 1991 law that increased city income tax to pay for Police Department's expansion. CAMPAIGN FINANCE -- Has proposed for the state a system like the one he initiated in the city, which includes spending limits and mandatory debates for candidates who accept it. Supports much lower limits on individual contributions to state races, tight restrictions on soft money and transfers from one political committee to another. HEALTH CARE -- Advocates government-subsidized health care for all, saying it is the only way to insure the three million New Yorkers without any coverage, but is unclear on how to pay for it. Says the state should relieve local governments of their Medicaid costs, but again does not say how to pay for it.

docs.lead_paragraph: Crouching by the door in his brown pants and pink hand-me-down shirt, Han Seung Ghil might have been preparing for his first day of kindergarten as he stared around the brightly painted room at the tangle of other boys jumping around him. Instead, Seung Ghil, who is 5, saw almost nothing through his mask of tears on the first day of what will probably become his life as an orphan.

headline.main: Seoul's Luckless Feel Pain And Look to Orphanages

docs.abstract: Children from very normal South Korean families are being left at orphanages in a indication of the psychological toll of country's economic tailspin, which has put hundreds of thousands of people out of work; other indications are a rise in insurance fraud, a rise in suicides and growing ranks of people living with relatives, in shelters or on the street; photos (M)
